The savings have allowed her to give her children an education and also to buy cake-making equipment.  The loan she is requesting is to buy sugar, flour, butter and other goods.

loans.use: To buy sugar, flour and butter for her business.

loans.name: Salah

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 42 years old and married with five children.

Salah has owned a shop since 1997, selling spare parts. He has a sufficient experience in this field, with a deep understanding of local customers and knowledge about their needs. He has a good reputation and he is well known in the surrounding areas.

He is requesting a $3000 loan in order to pay the annual rent for his workshop. He aims to gain more profits to improve his family’s life as a whole.

loans.use: to pay the annual rent for his workshop.

loans.name: Rachería La Carrera Group

texts.es:
El siguiente grupo tiene el nombre de “Ranchería la Carrera”, las integrantes de este grupo decidieron ponerle este nombre ya que así se llama la localidad donde ellos viven, ésta se caracteriza por ser una comunidad muy tranquila, es una comunidad pequeña y prácticamente todos los habitantes se conocen unos a otros, este grupo lo conforman siete mujeres muy optimistas y trabajadoras, las cuales decidieron unirse a este grupo porque en él vieron una buena oportunidad para desarrollar una actividad económica que pudiera ayudarles a contribuir en el sustento de su familia.
Los nombres de las integrantes y sus respectivas actividades son las siguientes:
1.- Rosa María G. (compra de 4 borregos y pastura)
2.- María Esthela S. (compra de borregos para vender)
3.- Marisela G. (compra de pollos para vender y alimento)
4.- Emma C. (compra de abarrotes para vender)
5.- María Angélica R. (compra de 5 borregos para vender)
6.- Celia M. (compra de 5 borregos para vender y pastura)
7.- Elidia H. (compra de 3 borregos para vender)
Doña Rosa María  es una mujer de 47 años de edad que estudió hasta el primer año de primaria, la cual se dedica al trabajo en el hogar, ella es la representante de este grupo y está casada desde hace 30 años con el señor Claudio Victor el cual se dedica a los trabajos de albañilería, juntos tienen 9 hijos, de los cuales 3 aún dependen de ellos y estudian en 1° de secundaria, 3° de secundaria y 2° de prepa. La señora Rosa es clienta de FRAC y es muy responsable y optimista, ella solicita este crédito porque ella se dedica la compra y venta de borregos y pollos, además de alimento y medicamentos para criarlos. Comenta que los pollos los compra en la veterinaria de su municipio para que estén sanos y a veces los compra también en su comunidad, y los borregos los compra en su comunidad, de esta manera los cría en su casa y desparasita, para posteriormente venderlos, comenta también que el tiempo necesario para que ella pueda vender sus animalitos es de 4 meses para vender sus pollitos y hasta un año para vender un borreguito, ella tiene 3 años de experiencia en este tipo de negocio por lo que sabe que le irá muy bien.  “Lo que yo hago es criar mis animalitos, cuando ya están listos los vendo y saco una ganancia y el dinero para volver a invertir y para la comida de mi familia, hasta ahorita el único problema que he enfrentado es que a veces se me enferman mis animalitos, más los borreguitos y en ocasiones se mueren por enfermedad,  pero estoy segura y confío que todo saldrá muy bien, porque en un futuro me gustaría seguir echándole ganas porque quiero poner un negocio de servilletas e hilos” Comenta doña Rosa con muchas esperanzas.
texts.en:
The following group is called “Ranchería la Carrera” (La Carrera Hamlet).  The members of this group decided on this name because that’s what the place they live in is called.  It’s characterized by being a tranquil community.  It is a very small community and practically all the residents know each other.  This group is formed by seven very optimistic, hardworking women who decided to join together in a group because they saw an opportunity to develop an economic activity that would help them contribute to their families’ support.

The names of the members and their respective activities are as follows:
1.- Rosa María G. (to buy four lambs and pasturage)
2.- María Esthela S. (to buy lambs to sell)
3.- Marisela G. (to buy chickens to sell and chicken feed)
4.- Emma C. (to buy groceries to sell)
5.- María Angélica R. (to buy 5 lambs to sell)
6.- Celia M. (to buy 5 lambs to sell and pasturage)
7.- Elidia H. (to buy 3 lambs to sell)

Rosa María, 47, only completed first grade.  She does house work.  She’s the group representative and has been married to Claudio Víctor for 30 years; he works as a bricklayer.  They have nine children three of which still are dependent on them and attend 7th, 9th and 11th grades.

Rosa is a FRAC client and is very responsible and optimistic.  She requests this loan because she buys and sells sheep and chickens and also for feed and medicine to raise them with. She comments that she buys the chicks at her town’s veterinary so that they will be healthy and sometimes she also buys them in her community; she buys the sheep in her community.  

She raises them at home and clears them of parasites in order to sell them later on.  She comments that it usually takes her four months to sell her chickens and up to a year to sell a little lamb.  She has three years’ experience in this type of business so she knows she’ll do very well.  “What I do is raise my little animals and when they are ready I sell them earning profits.  I reinvest the money and also use it for food for my family. To date, the only problem I’ve faced is that sometimes my little animals get sick, especially the little lambs, and they sometimes die of their illnesses.  But I’m sure and I trust that everything will turn out very well because I want to continue working hard because in the future I’d like to start a napkin and thread business,” Rosa comments hopefully.

loans.use: Ranchería la Carrera

loans.name: Mildred Carrascal Salas

texts.es: Mildred de 30 años es la propietaria de una miscelánea al sur de la ciudad, donde vive con su cónyuge y sus dos hijos en las edades de 7 a 10 años. Su negocio lo inició hace 6 años con muchas ganas de salir adelante, vendiendo productos mediante guías especializadas y con un pequeño capital prestado. Su clientela muy pronto empezó a crecer y sus sueños también, así fue como compró su primera vitrina hace un año, para definir un punto comercial de exhibición, hoy tiene 3 vitrinas y es líder de una compañía en la que trabaja con promotoras, mediante el sistema de multinivel. Su meta mas adelante es construir un segundo piso y por eso todos los días se levanta dispuesta a darlo todo en su negocio,  con el fin de lograrla. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará útiles escolares y de papelería  así como artículos de bisutería, con los cuales responderá a sus clientes, justamente con lo que ellos necesitan y esto es el éxito de su inversión Credikiva.
texts.en: Mildred, 30, owns a retail business in the south of the city.  She lives there with her partner and their two children who are 10- and 7-years old.  She started the business 6 years ago with a bit of borrowed money.  The business grew very quickly and she bought a display case a year ago.  She has three display cases now and leads a multilevel marketing business.  Mildred gets up every day and works hard to meet her goal: She wants to add a second floor to her house and the income from her business will pay for it.  She is applying to Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo for a loan, to be funded by Kiva, that she will use to stock her business with school supplies and other merchandise that her customers want.

loans.use: to stock her retail business.

loans.name: Dubis Mercado Villero

texts.es: Dubis de 29 años vive en Soledad con su cónyuge y su hija de 7 años; ella se dedica a generar ingresos mediante la venta de mercancía variada, que promociona utilizando guías especializadas de productos. Su negocio lo inició cuando una amiga le prestó la revista en la que ella vendía y Dubis se dedicó a promocionarla entre sus familiares y amigos mas cercanos; muy pronto otras personas empezaron a hacerle pedidos y su capital de trabajo se tornó insuficiente para lograr responderle a su clientela rápidamente, convirtiéndose esto en un gran desafío, porque para hacerlo necesita vincularse directamente a la revista, pues así obtendría un margen de ganancias superior y ofrecería mejores precios a su clientela. . Esta es justamente la razón por la cual acude a  su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará ropa interior, perfumes, bisutería y cremas; su inversión se torna exitosa en tanto no tendrá que utilizar intermediarios que incrementan el precio de venta de los artículos, accederá a descuentos especiales y responderá oportunamente a su clientela, para finalmente mas adelante cumplir su sueño de organizar un pequeño almacén, donde venda de todo un poco basada en la necesidad de la comunidad objeto de su atención.
texts.en: Dubis, 29, lives in Soledad with her partner and her 7-year old daughter.  She operates a business selling products that she buys from speciality catalogs.  She picked up the idea from a friend who operated a similar business and started selling to family and friends.  Her business grew so fast that she soon ran out of working capital.  She decided to order directly from her supplier to get a better margin and, in turn, better pricing for her customers.  She is applying to Fundacion Mario Santo Domingo for a Kiva loan that she will use to stock her business with underwear, perfumes, jewelry and creams.  She says the investment will allow her to buy merchandise directly from her supplier, rather than from an intermediary, something that will give her access to discounts and lower her costs.  Her goal for the future is to open a small general store where she could sell the kinds of products that her neighbors most want.

loans.use: to stock her retail business.

loans.name: El Trebol De Las Flores Group

texts.es:
Este grupo  se llama El trébol  de las flores esta conformado por  diez mujeres trabajadora y humildes originarias de santiago Pinotepa  un lugar donde la mayoría de sus ciudadanos son gente indígena  que visten con naguas y huipiles.
Una de las integrantes del grupo es la señora Leticia Araceli de treinta y seis años de edad es madre soltera, ella nos dice que se dedica a la venta de joyería desde hace siete años y lo que mas le gusta  de su negocio es tenerle los pedidos a sus clientas  a tiempo ya que la mayoría de los pedidos son para regalos de boda y XV años, 1° comunión, bautizos y cumpleaños.
Doña Leti como mejor  la conocen sus compañeras de grupo nos dice que anteriormente se dedicaba a la  organizar tantas pero siempre había querido tener su propio negocio así que empezó a comprar un poco de joyas en los meses de junio cuando los niños salen de las escuelas y empiezan las clausuras y se dio cuenta que era  un buen negocio así que con sus ganancias empezó a comprar mas  mercancía como son: aretes, cadenas, collares esclavas y arracadas.
Con el apoyo de fundacion pudo comprar  más cosas tanto de oro como de plata  para obtener más ganancias ya que sus clientes pequeños como son los niños de la secundaria quieren cosas mas económicas   fue entonces cuando decidió vender plata.
Doña Leti nos dice que siempre trabaja con amor ya que con sus ganancias y esfuerzo le ha dado una educación a su hija a quien quiere y apoya ya  que ella es madre y padre para su mejor tesoro que es su hija.
Ella pidió el préstamo para la compra de más mercancía de joyería como es: aretes, cadenas, collares, eclavas y arracadas.
Nos dice que esta muy agradecida con fundacion por apoyar a las madres solteras que desean  que sus hijos estudien.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son:
Lourdes Patricia- se  dedica a la venta  mercancía de abarrotes.
Adriana- se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Erika Verónica- se dedica a la venta de calzado.
Alicia – se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Aura-quien se dedica a la venta de  mercancía de abarrotes.
Deyne Maria-quien se dedica a la venta de mercancía de abarrotes.
Angelina-quien se dedica a la venta de calzado.
Maria del Rosario quien se dedica a la venta de  artículos de papelería.
Socorro-quien se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.

Le dan las gracias a fundacion por ayudarlas para que sus pequeños negocios crezcan y así puedan mejorar sus vidas.
texts.en:
This group is called “El Trébol de las Flores” and is composed of ten hardworking, humble women from Santiago Pinotepa, a place where most citizens are indigenous and still wear “naguas” and “huipiles” [traditional skirts and blouses].

One of the group members is Leticia Araceli, 36.  She is a single mother and she tells us that she has been selling jewelry for the last 7 years.  What she likes best about her business is having her customers’ orders ready on time since most of the orders are gifts for weddings, 15th birthday parties, 1st communions, baptisms and birthdays.

Leti, as she’s better known by her group members, tells us that she used to organize “tandas” [informal group savings schemes] but she’s always wanted to have her own business so she started to buy a little bit of jewelry in the month of June when children get out of school and vacations start and she noticed that it was a good business so she used her profits to buy more merchandise like earrings, chains, bracelets and hoop earrings.

With support from the Fundación she was able to buy more things both in gold and silver to obtain more profits since her younger customers like children in secondary school want less expensive items; this is when she decided to sell silver.

Leti tells us that she always works with love since with her profits and effort she's been able to provide an education for her daughter that she loves and wants to support since she’s both mother and father to her greatest treasure, her daughter.

She requested the loan to buy more jewelry merchandise like earrings, chains, necklaces, bracelets and hoop earrings.

She tells us that she’s very grateful to the Fundación for supporting single mothers who want their children to go to school.

The other group members are:

Lourdes Patricia- sells groceries.
Adriana- sells perfume.
Erika Verónica- sells footwear.
Alicia – sells Mexican fast food snacks.
Aura-sells groceries.
Deyne Maria-sells groceries.
Angelina-sells footwear.
Maria del Rosario- sells stationery supplies.
Socorro-sells Mexican fast food snacks.

They thank the Fundación for helping them so that their small businesses will grow and they can improve their lives.

loans.use: to buy jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Walter Antonio

texts.es:
Walter, vive con su familia, su esposa, sus hijos, y sus padres, para su familia solamente él trabaja, realizando labores agrícolas, este lo inicio con el apoyo de su padre, enseñándole el proceso para la siembra, no tiene un horario establecido ya que requiere de varios cuidos.
Él solicita un préstamo para la compra de insumos agrícolas como abono y herbicidas, para realizar la siembra de maíz, con esto se ayudara para darle los cuidados necesarios a la siembra y obtener una buena producción.
La aspiración de Walter es tener mejores cosechas, ya que este es el oficio que le genera lo necesario para alimentar a la familia, esperando que este préstamo le de lo necesario para lograrlo.
texts.en:
Walter lives with his family, including his wife, their children and his parents.  He works only for his family, and he is a farmer.  He started out in this line of work with the support of his father, who taught him how to cultivate crops.  He does not have a fixed work schedule, because he cares for his crops as needed.

He is requesting a loan to buy agricultural supplies such as organic fertilizer and herbicides for his corn crops.  This will help him to give his crops the care they require for their growth, so that he will get a good harvest.

Walter aspires to have better harvests, because it is with his crops that he generates the income needed to feed his family.  He is hoping that this loan will provide him with the means to achieve this.

loans.use: to buy farming supplies such as organic fertilizers and herbicides

loans.name: Bayasgalan Baarai

texts.en:
Bayasgalan is a 30-year-old man who lives with his parents in Hovd province in Western Mongolia.  He started an intercity transportation business in 2006.  He drives between the capital city and Hovd province.  Previously, he worked as an assistant driver for a company.  The advantages he has in the transportation business are that he knows the country roads well and that he is a professional driver.  He has a plan to expand his business by replacing the van with a minibus.  

Bayasgalan is a talented driver and says, "I would like my van to be repaired and to replace the wheels.  My van gets broken down due to the bad roads; therefore, it needs to be repaired.”  The total amount of the loan he is requesting is 2,000,000 MNT. He will use it to replace the wheels and make the repairs.

loans.use: to replace the wheels and make repairs to his van.

loans.name: Dodikhudo

texts.ru: Додихудо проживает в районе Кумсангир. Он женат. Ему 55 лет. У него один ребенок. Он имеет высшее образование. По профессии он филолог. На сегодняшний день Додихудо предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области он 10 лет. Кредит берет для обновления салона машины.
texts.en: Dodikhudo lives in the Qumsangir district.  He is 55 years old, married and has one child.  He has a higher education and is a philologist.  Today, Dodikhudo provides a taxi service.  He has been in this business for ten years.  He is requesting this loan to update his car interior.

loans.use: to update his car interior

loans.name: Vohid

texts.ru: Вохид проживает в районе Кумсангир. Он холост. Ему 22 года. Вохид занимается разведением крупнорогатого скота. Этим видом деятельности занимается два года. Кредит берет для закупа коровы.
texts.en: Vohid lives in the Qumsangir district.  He is 22 years old and single.  Vohid is involved in breeding cattle.  He has been in this business for two years.  He is requesting this loan to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Las Manzanas Group

texts.es:
El grupo de *las manzanas* esta conformado por hombres y mujeres muy trabajadores la localidad donde ellos estan establecidos es muy bonito sin embargo para llegar alla es un poco complicado porque no hay transporte, su localidad lleva por nombre Barrio Monte Alto.
El grupo de las manzanas se llama a si porque la localidad se caracteriza por los huertos de mazanas que existen.
Don Francisco quien es el representante del grupo tiene 31 años de edad vive en union libre con la señoara Reyna desde hace 10 años, juntos han procreado tres hijos Regina de 9 años, Lucila de 8 años, Cristian de 6 años los cuales todos se encuentran en primaria don Francisco se dedica a la construccion y carpinteria, pero  muy pronto abrira su tienda de ropa es por eso que ha solicitado el credito para comprar ropa de todo tipo, para dama, caballero, niño, niña y bebes.
Nos comenta que él no habia podido iniciar el negocio ya que los locales que tenia destinados para la venta de ropa no estaba aún terminado "Pero ahora que los he terminado estoy muy contento ya que podre iniciar el negocio aun no he pensado en el nombre pero lo seguire pensando" El credito le ayuada de mucho ya que podra comprar su mercancia y de ahi obtener ganacias.
uan de las metas de don Francisco es que su negocio que va a iniciar le valla muy bien y sobre todo que su clientela cresca.
Aun empieaza a tener ganacias pero comenta que cuando empieze a ganar sera para sacar adelante a sus hijos y sobretodo mejorra la caliada de vida.
los demas integrantes del grupo invertiran en:Marcelina en compra de borregos, Leticia en tienda de abarrotes,Victor y pedro invertiran en tienda de dulces, Beatriz en una polleria y Leonel en un taller mecanico. En general todo el grupo esta muy agradecido.
texts.en:
The “Las Manzanas” (The Apples) group is composed of very hardworking men and women from the community they live in.  It is very pretty however it’s somewhat complicated to reach because there is no transport available.  The community is called Barrio Monte Alto.  The “Las Manzanas” group is so named because the location is noted for the apple orchards that exist there.

Francisco, 31, is the group representative.  He has lived with his spouse, Reyna, for the last ten years and has three children: Regina, 9, Lucila, 8 and Cristian, 6.  All attend elementary school.  Francisco works in construction and carpentry but will soon open a clothing store and this is why he’s asking for the loan to buy all sorts of clothes for women, men, boys, girls and infants.

He comments that he hadn’t been able to start the business because the locales he’d destined for the clothing sales were unfinished.  “But now that I have finished them I’m very happy because I will be able to start the business.  I still haven’t thought of a name for it but I’ll keep thinking.”  The loan will help him much because he’ll be able to buy his merchandise and obtain profits from there.

One of Francisco’s goals is to do very well with the business he’s about to start and above all that his clientele grows.  He hasn’t started to earn profits yet but he comments that when he does they will be to move his children ahead and above all to improve quality of life.

The other group members will invest as follows:
Marcelina will buy lambs, Leticia in a grocery store, Victor and Pedro will invest in a candy store, Beatriz in a chicken shop and Leonel  in a repair shop.  In general, the entire group is very grateful.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: La Trinitaria Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama la trinitaria y se integra de tres señoras quien cada una se dedica  su actividad y se ubica en el barrio trinidad.

   Quien se le tomo  la entrevista se llama Maribel quine casada con el señor José Isabel con quien procreo   tres hijos que a un están a su  responsabilidad.

    Ella Solito el préstamo es para Invertirlo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su negocio de abarrotes en donde lleva trabajando un año y ocho meses en la que comenta que le va bien ya que con ello le ha dejado  buenos ingresos en su  hogar.

    Inicio  con esta actividad para así  apoyar así esposo con los ingresos de la casa  y darles lo más necesario a sus hijos que están estudiando.

     Lo que desea es que con esta pequeña actividad y el préstamo  logres agrandara mas su negocio  de abarrotes que la apoya con los ingresos de su hogar y así  podrá también ser  puntual en sus pagos.

Las que integran en el grupo son:

    María Bertha quien invertirá en la compra de mercancía para surtir su negocio  de abarrotes y la señora María Vida licia invertirá en la compra y venta de medicinales naturales.
texts.en:
This group is called “Trinitaria” and is composed of three women each with her own activity located in Barrio Trinidad.

Maribel was the person who was interviewed.  She’s married to José Isabel and they have three children still in their care.  She requested the loan to buy merchandise to stock her grocery store where she’s been working for a year and eight months.  She comments that she does well since it’s produced good income for her home.  She started with this activity in order to help out her husband with household income and provide her children who are attending school with what was most needed.

What she wants with this small activity and the loan is to manage to enlarge her grocery business that supports her home’s income more so that she will also be able to be punctual with her payments.

The other group members are:
María Bertha who will buy merchandise to stock her grocery store and María Vidalicia who will buy natural remedies to sell.

loans.use: to buy stock merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Maria Guadalupe

texts.es:
Doña Guadalupe vive en una comunidad llamada Concepcion el Chico para llegar a su casa se tiene que caminar mucho, doña Lupita como la conocen las vecinas de su comunidad tiene 61 años de edad ha vivido en union libre desde hace 33 años con sus pareja Hilario quien trabaja fuera del Estado de Mexico, dicha apareja ya no tiene dependientes sin embargo por el momento ellos se hacen cargo de sus nietos ya que su hija mama de los niños tuvo que salir a trabajar a la capital desde hace 15 dias. "Tengo que cuidar a mis nietos mandarlos a la escuela y recogerlos por la tarde".
Doña Lupita tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace 30 años la cual tiene por nombre la conchita, ella ha solicitado el credito para comprar abastecer su tienda comprando, pan, leche, huevo, refrescos, harina, golosinas, etc.
Siempre ha tenido la tienda aunque su tienda es muy sencilla y casi nunca la puede llenar por falta de dinero, siempre ha sido su gran dificultad conseguir un credito donde los intereses sean bajos y ella pueda pagar sobre todo porque ya no vende como cuando iniciaba su tienda ahora ya vende muy poco porque a sus alrededores tiene mucha competencia. 
La esperanza que tiene doña Lupita es que pueda recuperar sus ganacias de antes porque ella ha visto como habren nuevos negocios tambien los cierran muy facilmente.
"Yo estoy muy contenta por el credito otorgado por parte de FRAC y KIVA ya que esto le sera de gran ayuda para abastecer su tienda de abarrotes, espero no fallarles con la venta de la tienda y la papeleria de mi esposo Hilario esperemo no quedar mal"
texts.en:
Doña Guadalupe, 61, lives in a neighborhood called Concepcion El Chico, a place that's not easy to get to.  Doña Lupita, as she's known here, has lived with her partner, Hilario, for 33 years.  The couple takes care of their grandchildren because their daughter, the children's mother, left recently to work in the capital.  "I take care of my grandchildren", she says, "dropping them off at school and picking them up in the afternoon".  Doña Lupita has operated a corner grocery, called La Conchita, for 30 years.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to stock her store with the products--bread, milk, eggs, cold drinks, flour, snacks, etc.--that her customers demand. 
Although her store is small, she's never been able to fully stock it because she's never had the money to do so.  She's never had access to low-interest loan and her sales have fallen because there's a lot of competition in her neighborhood.  
Doña Lupita hopes this loan will allow her to recoup some of the business that she's lost and notes, mischievously, that many new businesses soon close.  
"I am very grateful to FRAC and KIVA", she say, "because this loan will help me stock my grocery".

loans.use: to stock her general store.

location.town: La concepcion, San Felipe del Progreso

loans.name: Khishigdelger Choijiljav

texts.en:
Mrs. Khishigdelger, who is 44, runs a small translation bureau with her husband in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. In a day she translates approximately 25-30 pages. She has been running her business for 9 years and has gained a lot of experience from her business.

Last winter, this couple purchased an old apartment with 3 rooms in the suburban district, but it needs a big repair to the most of its parts. Specifically, its living room, kitchen, and bathroom need to be fully renovated. Khishigdelger is planning to renovate it herself with her husband this April. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing the necessary building materials for her apartment repair.

loans.use: To purchase necessary building materials for her apartment repair.

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is a 40-year-old widowed woman who lives with her three children in Hovd province in Western Mongolia.  Two of her children study at the college and the youngest one studies at the high school. 

Purevsuren has been running a meat retailing business since 2007.  She brings in the supplies and trades them at a well-positioned shop counter.  She has been running the business successfully and has many regular customers.  This business is the only source of income for Purevsuren and her three children.  

Purevsuren is a motivated and hardworking woman who says, "I would like to raise the assets by buying some meat for the business."  The total amount of the loan she is requesting is 600,000 MNT.  She will use it to buy livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a 37-year-old married woman with three children aged 14, 10 and 7 years. She lives in the town of Trinidad, Bohol with her family.

Evelyn started a sari-sari store, or general store, business two years ago.  She sells items like toiletries, cooking oil, sugar and soft drinks.  Evelyn earns 2,000 PHP per month with her store.  Evelyn works hard to increase her earnings.  She plans to use her loan to purchase more items to sell such as beverages, sugar and canned goods. Evelyn plans to use any extra income to pay her children’s’ school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more items to sell such as beverages, sugar and canned goods.

loans.name: Ginalyn

texts.en:
Ginalyn has been in the fishing business for almost 10 years. She and her husband work together in their business. Ginalyn's husband operates their fishing boat and then she sells his catch at the market. She also buys and resells crabs.

Ginalyn does her best to improve their business and take care of their two children, who are ages 7 and 2. She applied for a loan to purchase fishing nets, floaters, lead for fishing weights, and nylon. Ginalyn hopes to buy home appliances with any extra income they earn.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets, floaters, lead for fishing weights, and nylon.

loans.name: Abdulatif

texts.ru: Абдулатиф занимается плетением веревок из ниток. Жена помогает плести нитки и они вместе развозят готовые веревки и сдают клиентам . Это ремесло осталось ему от матери. У них трое детей, двое сыновей женаты и дочь замужем. Все они работают и хорошо зарабатывают. Этим ремеслом Абдулатиф занимается 30 лет, почти с детства. Кредит получает для  покупки ниток, для дальнейшего плетения веревок.
texts.en: Abdulatif is involved in weaving ropes from threads.  His wife helps him weave threads, and together they deliver completed ropes and provide to clients.  This business was left to him from his mother.  Abdulatif and his wife have three children.  Two of their sons and a daughter are all married.  All of them also work and earn well.  Abdulatif has been involved in this business for 30 years, almost since his childhood.  He is requesting this loan to buy threads in order to continue weaving ropes.

loans.use: to buy threads

loans.name: Turdimurod

texts.ru: Турдимурод житель района Шахритус. Ему 26 лет. Он женат. У него один ребенок. Его жена занимается растениеводством. Сам он изготавливает деревянные окна и двери. Этим видом деятельности занимается восемь лет. Кредит берет для покупки досок, клея и красок.
texts.en: Turdimurod is a resident of the Shahrituz district.  He is 26 years old, married and has one child.  His wife is involved in agriculture.  Turdimurod manufactures wood window frames and doors.  He has been in this business for eight years.  He is requesting this loan to buy wood panels, glue and paint.

loans.use: to buy wood panels, glue and paint

loans.name: Imbaya's Group

texts.es:
Imaya's Group es una sociedad de cuatro personas responsables en su trabajo, en esta sociedad la presidenta es la chica de licra celeste se llama Silvana es presidenta debido a que es una persona estricta, de caracter fuerte, que le gusta salir adelante, Silvana vive con sus paás y sus dos hijos en Imbaya que se encuentra a 15 minutos de Ibarra en la Provincia de Imbabura.

Silvana trabaja sola en la crianza de pollos para engorde y posteriormente para venderlos, este negocio le ayuda económicamente para mantener a su hogar, ya que es el único ingreso que tiene es por eso que tiene que comprar crías constantemente para no quedarse sin animalitos, realiza su primer crédito con Fodemi con el propósito de comprar pollos para crianza y engorde, que ayudarán a que siga en el negocio y que siga vendiendo.

Silvana sueña con ser una distribuidora mayorista de Pollos.
texts.en:
"Imaya's Group" is a communal bank that includes 4 people who are responsible in their work.  The president of this group is the girl dressed in blue lycra leggings.  Her name is Silvana.  She is president because she is a disciplined person with a strong character, and she likes to get ahead.  Silvana lives with her parents and her two children in Imbaya, which is 15 minutes from Ibarra in the province of Imbabura.

Silvana works alone raising chickens to fatten and later sell.  This business helps her financially to support her household, because this is the only income that she has.  For this reason, she needs to constantly buy animals to raise so that she has work. She is taking her first loan with Fodemi, and her goal is to buy chickens to raise and fatten.  This will help her to continue with her business, so that she can continue to make sales.  

Silvana dreams of becoming a wholesale distributor of chickens.

loans.use: to buy chickens to raise and fatten

loans.name: Emeliana

texts.en:
54-year-old Emeliana is a married woman from Trinidad, Bohol.  She and her husband run farming and fishing businesses.

Emeliana has requested a loan for their fishing business.  She plans to purchase fishing nets, floats and lead for fishing weights.  Emeliana hopes to have enough money to buy a fishing boat soon.  She also hopes for her children, who still go to school, to be able to finish college in the future.

Emeliana is hopeful that this loan will help increase the business’ profits.

loans.use: to purchase fishing nets, floats and lead for fishing weights.

loans.name: Prisca's Group

texts.en:
Prisca's group is comprised of five hard-working women.  Prisca is 19 years old and lives in the town of Lukaya in the Masaka region of Uganda.  For the past two years, Prisca has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells milk. 

To help expand her business, Prisca has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase milk for resale, and will help Prisca to generate greater profits to pay for medical expenses and other family needs.  Prisca hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Prisca is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.  The ELA program has improved Prisca's future prospects by helping her to manage and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase milk for resale,

loans.name: Progress Group

texts.en:
This is Constance, a 29-year-old married woman from Masvingo in Zimbabwe. She has 2 children ages 6 and 1 year, and only 1 child goes to school. Constance is in the Agriculture business of poultry and has been in the business for a year now. She is currently operating her business from her place of residence and has an employee who helps her on a part time basis. 

Constance has requested a loan of $250 to buy stock feeds. With the extra income generated from this loan, she will be able to take care of her family well. Constance says some challenges being faced at the moment are of some chicks dying prematurely due to heat. In the next five years she would like to have a farm for raising chickens on a large scale.

loans.use: To buy stock feeds for her chickens.

loans.name: Husen

texts.ru: Хусен проживает в районе Дангара. Ему 55 лет. Он женат. У него шестеро детей. Он занимается скотоводством. Этим видом деятельности занимается три года. Кредит берет для закупа коровы.
texts.en: Husen lives in the Dangara district.  He is 55 years old, married and has six children.  He is involved in animal husbandry.  Husen has been in this business for three years.  He is requesting this loan to buy a cow.

loans.use: to buy a cow

loans.name: Hitolipo

texts.es:
Don Hipolito vive en la comunidad de Guadalupe Cote una comunidad que se caracteriza por estar en lo alto de un monte donde abundan los arboles grandes, Don Hipolito tiene 45 años de edad esta casado con la señora Juana aun tiene cuatro niños que dependen de ellos su hija de 13 años es quien aun estudia, el señor Hipolito y su familia se dedica a la elaboracion de pan para su venta, ha solicitado el credito para comprar harina, leche, levadura y leña porque aunque vive en un lugar donde abundan los arboles no puede cortar los arboles asi que se la leña se la traen de otro estado.
Nos relato como elabora el pan "Primero amaso la masa hasta que quede en forma para la elaboracion del pan, despues separo la masa en 120 gramos para cada pan, en otro lado se le da la forma del pan que es redonda pero tambien ahi selecciono los que van hacer, chicos, grandes y medianos cuando ya estan formados pasaran al horno de leña, donde tengo que estar atento ya que ser muy cuidadosos a la hora de cosinar voltear y una y otra vez para que no se quemen"
Don Hipolito tiene ya mucho tiempo haciendo el pan de monte desde que tenia 8 años de edad aprendio de su abuelo cuando cumplio 15 años el inicio su propio negocio. "El problema que enfrento muchas veces es la falta de recursos ya que la harina esta muy cara y por otro lado la leña que no dejan que la toquemos y tengo que traerla de otro lado y asi me sale super carisima"
Una de sus metas es tener una batidora para facilitar la elaboracion del pan porque produciendo mas pan sus ganacias puedan incrementar.
"Yo estoy muy agradecido por el credito autorizado por parte de FRAC y KIVA ya que en otras finacieras es muy dicifil que nos den el credito por los interes que cobran ya que son altisimos"
texts.en:
Hipólito lives in the community of Guadalupe Coté, a community noted for being on the top of a hill where large trees abound.  Hipólito is 45 years old and married to Juana.  He still has four children who depend on them and their 13 year old daughter is still attending school.  Hipólito and his family work baking bread to sell.  He’s asked for the loan to buy flour, milk, yeast and firewood because although he lives in a place where trees abound he cannot cut the trees down and firewood must be brought from another state.

He described to us how he makes the bread:  “First I knead the dough until it’s shaped to make bread.  Then I separate the dough into 120 gram portions for each piece of bread.  In another spot the bread is shaped usually into rounds but I also choose which will be made: small, large and medium.  Once formed they pass into the wood-burning oven where I have to be watchful and very careful while they are baking turning them over and over again so that they don’t burn.”

Hipólito has been baking mountain bread for a long time.  He learned from his grandfather when he was 8 years old and when he turned 15 he started his own business.  “The problem I face is that often resources are lacking since flour is very expensive.  On the other hand, we are not allowed to touch the wood and I have to bring it in from someplace else and it is super expensive that way.”

One of his goals is to have a mixer to make the bread more easily because by producing more his profits will increase.

“I am very grateful for the loan authorized by FRAC and KIVA because it’s very difficult to get loans from  other financial institutions because the interest rates they charge are very high.”

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, milk, firewood and yeast.

loans.name: Essam

texts.en: Essam is from Gaza. He owns a hair salon, which started on the 1st of January, 2011. He hopes to get this loan in order to buy an AC and finish  decorating his salon, which will increase the number of customers, leading to increased profit and income.

loans.use: To buy an AC and finish decorating his salon.

loans.name: Erdenebaatar Tudev

texts.en:
Erdenebaatar is 44 years old and lives with his wife and 3 children in Hovd province in Western Mongolia. His wife sells milk. Erdendbaatar has been running a taxi service business since 2009. It has been the only financial source for the family members. He has a car for the business.

He hopes to be able to afford a new van and wants to expand the business activity by purchasing a new van for his wife. He and his wife drive cars carefully and well. He is a diligent man who says, "I would like to expand the business by buying a new van for my wife so that we both can try together to raise the family income and improve the household." The total amount he is requesting to buy a van for his wife is 800,000 MNT.

loans.use: To buy a van.

loans.name: Godafreda

texts.en:
Godafreda earns a living by running a sari-sari (variety) store business in Trinidad, Bohol. She sells items like canned goods, instant noodles, detergent soap and palm vinegar. She is able to help provide for her family's daily needs with the income she earns from the store.

She is requesting a loan to buy more items to sell, such as coffee, vinegar and soft drinks. Godafreda hopes to have a stable income. She said she will do her best to be a responsible borrower.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as coffee, vinegar and soft drinks.

loans.name: Rebeccah

texts.en: Rebeccah is a 37-year-old married woman. She has 2 children ages 4 and 7. She describes herself as a visionary woman. She operates a motor vehicle where she provides transportation services. She has been involved in this business for 3 years and employs 2 staff members. Her business is located at a busy road and her primary customers are public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy motor vehicle spare parts. Her business goal is to expand this business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Artesanos Del Oro Group

texts.es:
El grupo de los "Artesanos del Oro" esta integrado por 7 integrantes dos mujeres y 5 hombres son personas muy trabajadoras ellos decidieron ponerle asi porque se dedican a la artesania del ocochal y por el lugar donde viven, viven en un municipio llamado el Oro es un lugar muy bonito por sus casas que se ven que son de tiempo atras.
Magalli tiene 22 años es soltera acaba de estudiar licenciatura en Psicología aun vive con sus padres, ella se dedica a la artesania esta vez ha solicitado el credito para comprar el complemeto de laton, Magalli compra el ocochal para armar articulos como servilleteros, tortilleros, papetes, porta calientes etc, ella solo compra el laton que son pequeñps detalles que le pone a los articulos del ocochal, ya armados Magalli puede venderlos al mejor precio que ella cree conveniente.
Ella solo vende en temporadas se podria decir que es una de sus dificultades ya que no tiene oportunidad de vender en varias acaciones sus clientes llegan a pedirle encargos o pedidos para ocaciones especiales, pero son muy pocas veces, una de sus metas que tiene es titularse en Psicologia ya que por el momento solo tiene la carta pasante y le gustaria llegar a titularse y trabajar como Psicologa, "Estoy muy agradecida con el credito que FRAC Y KIVA me otorgaron ya gracias al credito que me ofrecieron en ciclos anteriores yo tenia para comprar el material y armar mis articulos para despues venderlos y de ahi sacar para mis colegiaturas, libros y pasajes"
Tambien los demas integrantes del grupo estan muy agradecidos por el prestamo ya que podran invertir en sus negocios Miguel, Abigail, Eulogio, invertiran en su artesania, J. Carmen en Carpinteria, Sergio en Taxi y Antonio en su farmacia veterinario.
texts.en:
The Artesanos del Oro group has 7 members, two women and 5 men.  They operate businesses making and selling "ocochal" (a traditional craft).  The members live in the town of El Oro, a beautiful place with houses that seem to belong to another time.  
Magalli, 22, is single.  She just finished a degree in psychology and lives with her parents.  She is applying for a loan that she will use to buy supplies of brass.  She will make ocochal placemats and other tableware.  She will use the supply of brass to decorate her ocochal products, something that will allow her to fetch a better price for them.  
Magalli says that her customers only want her products at certain times of the year, something that's a problem for her because she can't sell year-round.  She wants to go back to school to complete a higher degree in psychology because she only has a "carta pasante" now and she'd like to get an advanced degree that would allow her to work as a psychologist.  "I am very grateful to FRAC and KIVA for helping me", she says, "because past loans have helped me to to make the products that I sell".  She adds that her income from the business paid her school fees, books, etc.  
The other members are also grateful for your loans.  Miguel, Abigail and Eulogio used their share of the loan to support their crafts business; J. Carmen, his carpentry business; Sergio, his taxi business; and Antonio, his veterinary pharmacy business.

loans.use: to buy ocochal for their crafts businesses.

loans.name: David Kamau

texts.en:
David is a 42-year-old married man. He has two children with ages ranging from 6 years to 9 years.

He describes himself to be an aggressive man. He operates a motor vehicle with which he provides transportation services. He has been involved in this business for 5 years and employs 2 staff members. His business is located at a busy road and his primary customers are the public.

David will use the loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy motor vehicle spare parts. His business goal is to expand his business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Ruvimbo Group

texts.en:
Rebecca is a 40-year-old married lady from Masvingo, Zimbabwe and has five children ages 19, 16, 13, 8, and 2 years. Three of them are still going to school.

Rebecca has a service activity business of a hair and beauty salon that she operates from her residential place. During her spare time she also does a bit of sewing. She has been in the business for more than 13 years and is partially doing well. 

Rebecca is requesting a loan of $400 to buy hair and beauty chemicals. With the income generated from this loan, Rebecca will be able to pay school fees and buy food for her family. The challenge she faces in the business is competition that causes her to change her prices every time. However, she has a vision of opening a much bigger salon in town in the next 5 years.

loans.use: to buy hair and beauty chemicals.

loans.name: Unity Is Power Group

texts.en:
Magret is a 55-year-old married lady from Masvingo, Zimbabwe, with 3 children aged 35, 33 and 32 years. None of them are still at school. She has 3 dependents. She stays with her grandchildren. 

She is in a retail business of buying and selling clothes, and she operates from her residence. She has been in the business for 15 years and does not have any employees working for her. High costs of duty at the point of entry, bad debts and high competition are some of the challenges she faces in the business.

She has requested a loan of $200 to buy some clothes for resale. With the income generated from this loan, Magret will be able to pay for the grandchildren she is staying with. In the next five years she is planning to have a boutique in town.

loans.use: to buy a stock of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ines

texts.en:
Ines is a married woman who lives in the town of Trinidad, Bohol. She is 41 years old and has 3 children. Ines's husband is a fisherman.

Ines works with her husband doing the fishing. She sells his catch at their town's market. Ines is doing her best to improve their business and her family's living conditions. She requested a loan to repair their fishing boat. She plans to purchase marine plywood, epoxy and paint for the boat. She hopes for a better income so she can sustain her children's education.

loans.use: to purchase marine plywood, epoxy and paint for the boat.

loans.name: Moses Macharia

texts.en: Moses is a married man. He has 2 children, ages 4 months and 4 years. He describes himself to be an aggressive man. He operates a motor vehicle where he provides transportation services. He has been involved in this business for 5 years and employs 2 staff members. His business is located at a busy road and his primary customers are public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. He will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy motor vehicle spare parts. His business goal is to expand his business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy motor vehicle spare parts.

loans.name: Sector Los Olivos  (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Sector los Olivos está formado por 10 socias y 1 socio quienes viven por los sectores aledaños de la parroquia de Turi que está localizada al sur de la ciudad de Cuenca que se caracteriza por sus paisajes, por su cultura y artesanía, y por su arquitectura vernácula. Su gente se dedica al comercio, cría de animales y agricultura.  Los integrantes de este grupo son personas muy luchadoras, trabajadoras y siempre ven los obstáculos como retos para superarse y salir adelante, mantienen la cultura y tradiciones de sus padres, son amables, gentiles y de un corazón muy cálido. 

Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora. Rosa Inés, tiene 50 años, es casada y en su unión conyugal ha concebido 3 hijos quienes son todos mayores de edad, dos de sus hijos son casados y viven independientes, su última hija  estudia en una universidad de la ciudad y también trabaja para costearse sus gastos. Su esposo labora como carpintero, la casa en la que habitan es de su propiedad.

Doña Rosa Inés se dedica desde hace 20 años a la agricultura, siembra y comprar hortalizas para la venta, las mismas que las vende en un mercado de la ciudad. También se dedica a la cría de cerdos, cuyes, pollos y patos.
 
Es socia del banco comunal hace 4 años y su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de alimento para sus animales.
 
Su meta es crecer en sus negocios.
texts.en:
The “Sector Los Olivos” (Olive Tree Sector) communal bank has ten female and one male member who live in sectors adjacent to Turi Parish which is in the south of the city of Cuenca and is notable because of its scenery, its culture and crafts and for its native architecture.  Its residents are merchants, raise animals and farm.  The members are tenacious, hardworking people who see obstacles as challenges to overcome and continue forward.  They preserve the culture and traditions of their parents.  They are kind, pleasant people who are very warmhearted.

One of the members of this group is Rosa Inés.  She’s 50 years old, married and has three children who are all adults.  Two of her children are married and live independently and her youngest daughter who attends a university in the city also works to cover her expenses.  Her husband works as a carpenter and the house they live in is theirs.

Rosa Inés has been farming for the last 20 years; she plants and buys vegetables to sell in a market in the city.  She also raises pigs, guinea pigs, chickens and ducks.

She’s been a member of the communal bank for four years and will use her loan to buy animal feed.  Her goal is to grow in her businesses.

loans.use: to buy animal feed.

loans.name: Emiliano Zapata Jicayan Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama Emiliano Zapata Jicayan y esta  conformado por  cuatro integrantes  mujeres indígenas  originarias de san Juanito Jicayan un pueblo bonito donde hay personas nobles, antes de llegar a san Juanito esta  un rió grande con árboles verdes.
Las integrantes de este grupo hablan el idioma  mixteco ellas nos dicen que están orgullosas de ser de San Juanito de sus culturas y de su lengua.
Una de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora  Irlanda  una señora trabajadora  de veinte seis años de  edad, ella nos dice que se considera una mujer trabajadora y humilde con deseos de superación.
Ella se dedica a la venta de dulces y comida como  son: empanadas de pollo, tostadas, tacos dorados y  sopes.
Ellas nos cuenta una de sus experiencias en su trabajo:
Nos dice que anteriormente se dedicaba solamente a la venta de dulces en una escuela pero con el apoyo de fundacion compró ingredientes para la elaboración de comida como es: chile verde, Chile seco, tomate, cebolla, queso, carnes  frías, quesillo y maíz para la elaboración de tortillas.
Lo que mas le gusta de su negocio es que poco a poco y con trabajo a podido hacerlo crecer y de sus mismas ganancias preparar mas platillos.
Ella nos dice que la comida que elabora y los dulces los vende en una escuela de su comunidad  y lo que mas le gusta de vender  en la escuela es la confianza de darle una buena alimentación a los niños y cuidarlos ya que les ayuda a que se laven  las manos y que coman a gusto y sabroso.
Ella va utilizar el préstamo para la compra de más ingredientes para la elaboración de comida, dulces y frutas para los niños de la escuela también coman frutas.
Le da las gracias a fundacion por ayudarla y hacer que sueños se realicen igual los sueños de los niños se hagan realidad ya que ella como madre trabaja para  su hijo Arisbel  y así como ella trabaja hay muchos padres que trabajan para el futuro de sus hijos, ella nos dice que se siente afortunada de contar con el apoyo de fundacion.
Las otras integrantes son:
Fabiola-se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Maria-se dedica a la venta de abarrotes.
Guadalupe-se dedica a la venta de antojitos.
Le dan las gracias a fundacion por ayudarlas a que sus vidas mejoran ya que desean darle una mejor vida a sus hijos par que  tengan una mejor educación y así tener un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
This group is called “Emiliano Zapata Jicayan” and is composed of four indigenous women from San Juanito Jicayan, a pretty town inhabited by honorable people.  Just outside of San Juanito there is a large river with green trees.  The members of this group speak Mixteco and they tell us that they are proud of being from San Juanito and of their culture and language.

One of the group members is Irlanda, a 26 year old, hardworking woman.  She tells us that she considers herself to be a hardworking, humble woman who wants to improve herself.  She sells candy and food like: chicken turnovers, tostadas, fried tacos and sopes [a circle of fried masa with pinched sides. This is then topped with refried beans and crumbled cheese, lettuce, onions, red or green sauce and sour cream. 

She relates one of her work experiences:

She relates that she used to just sell candy at a school but with support from the Fundación she bought ingredients to prepare dishes like: green chili, dried chilies, tomatoes, onions, cheese, cold cuts, string cheese and corn to make tortillas.

What she likes best about her business is that little by little and with work she’s made it grow and with her same profits to prepare more dishes.  She tells us that she sells the food she prepares and the candy at a school in her community and what she likes best is selling at school trusting that she’s providing the children with good food and caring for them since she helps them wash their hands and to eat tasty food comfortably. She will use the loan to buy more ingredients to prepare food, candy and fruit so that the school children will also eat fruit.

She thanks the Fundación for helping her and making her dreams a reality as well as the dreams of the children since she, as a mother, works for her son, Arisbel, and just like she works so too there are many other parents that work for their children’s future.  She tells us that she feels fortunate to have the Fundación’s support.

The other members are:
Fabiola-will sell perfume.
Maria-sells groceries.
Guadalupe-sells fast food snacks.

They thank the Fundación for helping them improve their lives since they want to provide better lives for their children so that they can have better educations and thus better futures.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for food preparation.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
This is Flora, 43, resident of Bacoor, Cavite city, Philippines. Her husband is Antonio, who works on a maintenance crew. She is a mother of her three children. She manages their household while operating her business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 

Flora operates an accessories retail business. What she basically does is buy accessory items from wholesalers and sells them per piece/pack for a profit. Products can range from beaded jewelry like necklaces to other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. She also manages a barbeque stall for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php13,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of accessory products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Flora hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business.  She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of accessory products needed in her business

loans.name: Kuwirirana Group

texts.en:
This is 59-year-old Letitia from Harare. She is widowed with two children.  Letitia runs a retail business selling clothes, blankets and footwear. The business has been in operation for 3 years. She says the main challenge faced is poor shelter at the market. 

Letitia has requested a loan of $500 to buy blankets and winter wear for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to assist in the upkeep of her family. In the future, Letitia plans to open a shop in the Central Business District of Harare.

loans.use: to buy blankets and winter wear for resale.

loans.name: Munhzul

texts.en:
Munhzul is a 35-year-old woman who lives with her husband and 5 children in Govisumber province in Southern Mongolia. Her husband works as a co-driver for NIC company. Three of her children go to the secondary school, a son goes to kindergarten and the youngest one is a newborn child. 

She has been running a food cart business for 7 years. She goes to the train station and sells the prepared food and other traditional food. This has been a really profitable business because the Transiberian train passes by. 

She is a professional cook and always attends the training and seminars related to the entrepreneurship. Now she plans to expand the business activity. Munhzul is an intelligent woman who says, "I would like to expand my business activity by buying supplies like 50 kilograms of mutton and 35 kilograms of chevon (goat meat)." The total amount she is requesting is 750,000 MNT to buy meat for the business.

loans.use: To buy meat for her business.

loans.name: Francis Mwaura

texts.en: Francis is a 46-year-old married man. He has a daughter who is 18 years old. He describes himself to be an aggressive man. He operates a motor vehicle business where he provides transportation services. He has been involved in this business for 3 years and employs 2 staff members. His business is located on a busy road and his primary customers are public. He describes his biggest business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy motor vehicle spare parts. His business goal is to run a well-established transportation services business within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy motor vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has 4 children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of an additional family member (niece). 

Betty has a business of a retail shop. She has been in this business for 5 years, and she works 7 days a week. Betty sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. Betty has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap, maize, flour, and rice.    
 
The main business challenges for Betty includes transportation and the ever-increasing prices of commodities in Uganda. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully-stocked shop and to own a delivery van to ease in the transportation of commodities. 

Betty lives in a home that she owns. She has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more boxes of soap, bags of sugar, rice, maize, flour, and cartons of salt

loans.name: Gantsetseg

texts.en:
Gantsetseg is a 47-year-old woman who lives with her husband and a son in the Bayanhongor province in southwestern Mongolia. Her husband is unemployed and her son studies at the high school.

Gantsetseg has been running a food retailing business since 2000. She has her own kiosk in the area of the big trade center. She buys the supplies in wholesale and her husband helps with the business activity. There are number of regular customers for the business and it has been successful in the last 12 years.

Gantsetseg has a further plan to expand the business and she says that "I would like to expand the business activity by buying the food products in large quantities. I plan to open a shop with the income I earn." The total amount she is requesting is 300,000 Mongolian Tugrik (MNT) to buy the food products.

loans.use: To buy food products.

loans.name: Arnelfa

texts.en:
This is Arnelfa, 32, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Neil, a policeman, and a mother to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.          
                   
Arnelfa operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Arnelfa hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Kahramon

texts.ru: Кахрамон проживает в районе Дангара. Ему 37 лет. Он женат. У него четверо детей. Он предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области он три года. Кредит берет для ремонта автомашины.
texts.en: Kahramon lives in the region of Dangara. He is 37 years old, married and has four children. He provides a taxi service. He has been in this business for three years. Kahramon is taking out the loan to repair the car.

loans.use: to repair the car.

loans.name: Yojaira Sixta Guerra Cavadia

texts.es: Yohaira de 40 años,  tienen 3 hijas en las edades de 12 a 18 años, con los que sueña ver convertidas en personas exitosas; por eso se esmera trabajando en su negocio, mediante el cual  confecciona prendas de vestir para damas, caballeros, niños y niñas. Ella tiene su propio  taller funcionando desde 2007 en su residencia familiar,  en la parte delantera de la sala, con una infraestructura física adecuada a su actual nivel de producción y ventas. Su experiencia data de 16 años, cuando su madre le enseñó este oficio. Sus clientes principales son amigos, familiares, referidos y personas ocasionales. Yohaira vende de contado, por anticipos y con plazos hasta de 15 días. También labora medio tiempo en un taller de confecciones ubicado cerca a su casa. Sus proveedores son los almacenes de telas y accesorios del centro de Barranquilla, a quienes les compra de contado las materias primas. El negocio de Yohaira presenta unas razones de liquidez excelentes, pero quiere hacer una inversión fija y su capital de trabajo le resulta insuficiente y es su gran desafío. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, ella espera con él,  hacer una inversión en inventario de materias primas y en una  fileteadora industrial, con la que aumentará la cantidad y la calidad de la ropa que confecciona; así, atenderá oportunamente a la clientela, pues se acercan fechas especiales, como el día de la secretaria y de la madre, por lo que su negocio debe estar preparado para el incremento en las ventas esperado y esto es justamente lo que hace que su credikiva sea una inversión exitosa.
texts.en:
Yojaira is 40, and has three daughters between the ages of 12 and 18. She dreams of them becoming successful people, and that's why she makes such a great effort working in her business, in which she makes articles of ladies', men's and children's clothing. She has her own workshop, operating in her home since 2007, located in the back part of the main room. It has a physical infrastructure adequate for her current level of production and sales. 

She has 16 years of experience, going back to the time her mother taught her this trade. Her main clients are friends, family members, referrals, and drop-ins. 

Yojaira sells for cash, through advance payments, and through installments up to two weeks. She also works half-time in a dressmaking workshop located near her home. Her suppliers are the fabric and accessories stores in the central area of Barranquilla, from which she buys her raw materials for cash. 

Yojaira's business displays excellent liquidity ratios, but she wants to make a fixed investment; and her working capital is proving to be insufficient, and is a big challenge. 

This is the reason why she is applying for her credikiva loan, the first loan she is taking out with Fundacíon Mario Santo Domingo. With it, she hopes to invest in her inventory of raw materials and in an industrial serger. This way, she will increase the quantity and the quality of the clothing she makes.

She will be able to serve her customers in a timely way, as special dates are approaching, such as Secretary's Day and Mother's Day. Her business must be ready for the expected increase in sales, and this is precisely what will make her credikiva a successful investment.

loans.use: To invest in raw materials and in an industrial serger.

loans.name: Las Florecitas Group

texts.es:
Este  grupo se llama "Las florecitas" esta conformado por  nueve mujeres trabajadoras con deseos de tener una mejor calidad de vida y mejorar el futuro de sus hijos.
Las integrantes de este grupo son originarias de Pinotepa nacional  tierra de  oportunidades y de gente indígena.
Una de las integrantes  es la señora  Esther una señora  trabajadora  que se dedica a la  venta de ropa desde  hace dos años.
Esta felizmente casada con el señor  Filiberto un señor trabajador que  se dedica a  trabajar de albañil.
Tiene tres hijos ellos son el futuro para que ella trabaje y le eche ganas a lo que hace ya que desea mejorar la vida de sus tres hijos.
Pidió el préstamo para la compra de más ropa  para dama, caballero y niña.
Nos cuenta que su negocio le deja buenas ganancias sale a vender su mercancía  en las calles de su comunidad.
Esta muy contenta por el apoyo que le ha dado fundacion para que su negocio crezca y pueda triunfar en la vida.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son: 
Isidra Luisa-quien se dedica a la venta de calzado.
Gregoria-quien se  dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Soledad-quien se dedica a la venta de guisados.
Paula-quien se dedica a la venta de pollos.
Rosario Yuridia -quien se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Maria Inés-quien se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Claudia-quien se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Cristina-quien se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.

Len dan las gracias a fundacion por ayudarlas para que sus negocios crezcan y así  mejorar el futuro de sus hijos.
*Hay una señora adicional en la foto, ella solo es amiga del grupo, pero quizo aparecer en la fotografía
texts.en:
The nine women of the Las Florecitas group are working hard to create a better future for themselves and their children.  
All the members of the group are from Pinotepa, the land of opportunity.  
Our member, Sra. Esther, is a hard-working woman who operates a clothing sales business.  
She is happily married, to Sr. Fiilberto, a construction worker.  
She has three children, her reason for working hard and building a better future.  
She is applying for a loan that she will use to buy clothing for men, women and children.  
She tells us that she works as a street vendor and that she's happy with her income from the business.  
She is grateful for your support because past loans have helped her to grow her business and get ahead in the world.  
The other members of the group are:
Isidra Luisa who operates a business selling footwear.
Gregoria who operates a business selling prepared meals.
Soledad who opeates a business selling prepared meals.
Paula who operates a business selling poultry.
Rosario Yuridia who operates a business sell prepared meals.
Maria Ines who operates a business selling perfumes.
Claudia who operates a business selling perfumes.
Cristina who operates a business selling prepared meals.
All say that they are grateful to the Foundation for helping them grow their businesses and create better futures for their children.  
* One of the women in the photo is not a member of the group, but a friend of a member.

loans.use: to stock her clothing sales business.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is a 44-year-old married woman. She has 6 children with ages ranging from 8 years to 28 years. She describes herself to be hardworking. She operates a motor vehicle business, where she provides transportation services. She has been involved in this business for 10 years and employs 2 staff members. Her business is located at a murram and busy road and her primary customers are public. She describes her biggest business challenge to be stiff competition within the area. She will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy motor vehicle spare parts. Her business goal is to run a well-established transportation services business.

loans.use: to buy motor vehicle spare parts

loans.name: Progressive Group

texts.en:
Tawanda is a 35-year-old married man from Masvingo, Zimbabwe, who has two children, aged seven and three years. One of his children goes to a local primary school. He has three other dependents, including his sister's child and younger brother, who stay with him. 

Tawanda operates a flea market stall in town and he buys his products from South Africa. He has been in this business for seven years and he has one employee working for him. He has requested a loan of $600 to buy more clothes for resale. With the income generated from this loan, Tawanda will be able to provide for a better future for his children. He faces the challenge of high competition in the market, but he is however planning to open his own boutique in town in the next five years.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Bayarjargal Batsuuri

texts.en:
Mr. Bayarjargal, age 23, is unmarried and lives with his parents and his sister in the suburban district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He works as a salesman in a private computer distributing company and takes home a bonus of $18 USD from computer sales.

Bayarjargal has been running his business for a year and has saved some money for his future life. He plans to move out from his parents' home this summer. He is purchasing an apartment with a room in which to live with his fiancee, but he lacks the money to cover the cost of its advance fee. The loan he is taking will be dedicated to cover the cost of his purchasing a new apartment to start his own individual life.

loans.use: to purchase a new apartment to start his own individual life.

loans.name: Tsedevsuren

texts.en:
Tsedevsuren is a 35-year-old man who lives with his wife and a son in Bayanhongor province in southwestern Mongolia. His wife is a herder and his son studies at the secondary school.

Tsedevsuren has been running a welding business since 2002. He makes the oven and other other auto repairing at home. He also sells the various kinds of ovens, cookers, and chimneys, which are all made by him. He is a talented welder with the further plan to expand the business activity.

Tsedevsuren is a diligent man who says "I would like to expand the business activity by buying the necessary equipment like cutter for the woods so that I could cut the woods for the customers." The total amount he is requesting is 1,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to buy equipment and necessary materials.

loans.use: To buy equipment and necessary materials.

loans.name: Luzinda

texts.en:
This is Luzinda, 50, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines.  She is married to Domingo, a driver, and a mother to her three children.  Together with her husband she manages the household while operating her business.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for everyday expenses.                      
       
Luzinda operates a variety store.  In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to members of the local neighborhood.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil or an egg.  She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece.  Her store is located adjacent to her house.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of 11,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Luzinda hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education.  She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners and/or clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Robelyn

texts.en:
This is Robelyn, 27, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines.  She is married to Roger, a salesman, and a mother to her two children.  Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating her business.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for everyday expenses.                       
      
Robelyn operates a variety store.  In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages in small quantities to members of the local neighborhood.  It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP worth of cooking oil or an egg.  She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece.  Her store is located adjacent to her house.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and members of the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory.  She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Robelyn hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education.  She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners and/or clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis.  A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners.  The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is a widowed woman. She has 4 children with ages ranging from 9 months to 23 years. She describes herself to be aggressive. She operates a food stall where she sells fish. She has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her business is located in a busy area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the lack of proper storage for the fish. She will use the Kes 15,000 loan to buy more fish for selling. Her business goal is to expand her business within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more fish for selling.

loans.name: Emma Revelo

texts.en:
This is Emma, 42, resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Cerilo, a carpenter, and a mother to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business.
